es2Uul7UNHjWByu3v4xDBA.text: Terrible experience with this restaurant. Totally biased towards Asians. My other classmates who visited there were asked to sit at the bar table when there are proper tables available.My friend and I went there with children and the waitress simply said they do not allow children under 13 to eat there!! Very bluntWe went there because friends recommendation of food. But without good services, good food sucks

MFUk5qU4UsxZ7Cc4qxLexw.text: I want to preface my review that I was not very hungry when I went as part of a business dinner.  I found it nice but it all felt a little phony, from the button to get champagne to the banter with the servers.  I started with steak tartare, which was prepared well and had many layers of flavor.  Indulged in the caviar option, which was a nice touch.Made the mistake of going with salmon tartare as a main.  The issue was not the quality but it was prepared exactly like the steak tartare and tasted almost identical.  Probably my mistake but had assumed there would have been more variance.Overall, a good meal that did not blow me away.

Eo_Y7ynZ3dPNv4xuIITAkQ.text: If you go to restaurants for the food, try elsewhere. It's a gorgeous restaurant with a stylish atmosphere and the instagrammable champagne button, but the staff is a bit cold and the food was subpar. We had reservations but the man at the front was rude when we showed the booking code when he couldn't find it and gave us the worst seat in the place (right next to the door, where everyone walked past us and was noisy all evening). If you're looking for tepid peas in a cold caviar tin, try Bob Bob if your local pet shop is out. The dumplings were lukewarm inside, albeit tasty, and the vegetables on the side were the same, minus the tasty. The one thing making the meal not completely regrettable was the strawberry soufflé, which is not as like-worthy as the chocolate bomb but perfectly cooked. There are other pretty places in London to go that have excellent food to match, so do your tastebuds a favor and skip Bob Bob.

photos.caption: Photo of Bob Bob Ricard - Soho, London, United Kingdom. strawberries and cream souffle

VbFN-2Q-X1yLoZn9-LQyhg.text: After reading about this restaurant for our upcoming trip to London I was super excited to make reservations and see what was so great. Unfortunately...it left much to be desired. Who knows, maybe it was that the food just fell flat of our expectations. We ordered the beef Wellington and it was OK, nothing special. We also shared a salad and some bread (which if you ask for more they charge you extra). The worst part was that I made reservations to celebrate my husband's birthday and he was not a fan by the end of the meal. Service was good but honestly the flavor was severely lacking in every way.In hindsight I gather this is more of a place to go just because it looks interesting inside (and sure they have a button to press for champagne) but those things aside, I'd recommend saving your money for another place in the city.

Gy2fu1rf5akIoAySzq6Kgg.text: Push a button and - ¡voila! - champagne! So much fun. The ambiance of Bob Bob Ricard is elegant and gorgeous. I loved the dark wallpaper, the crystal glasses and gold-rimmed plates. Even our desserts sparkled. Service was excellent. And I was very impressed that they did not give us a hard time about not ordering full-course meals. We decided to order a bottle of champagne, a few appetizers and focus on dessert. The Beef Wellington looked divine do I would like to come back and try that someday. The lobster macaroni and cheese was every bit as decadent as expected. My friends like their beef tartare. The only reason this isn't 5 stars is because I didn't think that the gorgeous, melting desserts we'd been dying to try were as tasty as they were pretty. We tried the Eton Mess en Perle and the Chocolate Fondant. Both desserts were served with chocolate shells that melted when topped with warm sauces. Very pretty and fun - especially after some champagne!

R8FBr-NKigl-06qsyiyC8A.text: Bob Bob Ricard is amazing, heard a lot about this place, from know food critics to friends who have eaten here. And its been 50/50. Now that I have been, I side with this place is a definite place to try. The venue itself is unique and has a flare for the dramatics and endearing. Art decor theme with part godfather feel, part Russian oligarch.  A lot of attention in the details from the floors to the napkins and booths. We sat downstairs, which I believe has more of a romantic feel. The food was brilliant, I remember I wanted to order different things, try different things. Its a fusion of Russian and bistro. Deserts was amazing too, finally got to try that instagramable chocolate ball thing. Very rich, and very fun. Customer service was top notch, every staff was hand on deck. The cost was dear though, and not something I can do everyday, but thoroughly enjoyed myself and glad I went.

rYgr3MXiBJ5D3O5VbJb_jg.text: Decor: Art Deco chic and very chic at that. All the accouterments you want in a high end dining experience. Food and drink: excellent and great interesting. Great mix of Eastern Europeans and British dishes. Makes it a great special occasion restaurant. Get the desserts and the sub zero vodka shots!Service: fantastic. True fine dining levels.

kt0aMUEzVSGYQ3jUR3Rizw.text: Insanely cute decor, great food, and a "Press for Champagne" button table side.. 5 stars!There are two floors here, the ground floor is all blue, and the downstairs is all red. If you can request to be seated downstairs, the atmosphere is much better! You want to take a million photos down there because the space feels so special. We were seated at a big booth along the wall, with a bucket for champagne waiting tableside and a button to call for drinks on the wall. Although the champagne is the theme, we started with cocktails (and still rang the Champagne button :) )! The Passionfruit Martini was a perfect girly drink to start off our girls night right!Food wise, my friend had been here before, so she spouted off all her favorites and we ordered pretty much everything she loved - Baked oysters, Potato Vareniki, Sole stuffed with seafood and champagne sauce, and truffle mashed potatoes. We also ordered the corn to make sure we had enough side options. If you like truffles (like I do!), our menu is for you- as the oysters, Vareniki and potatoes all come smothered in delicious truffle sauces.The baked oysters where honestly the best thing I've ever tasted, cheesy, truffle-y, and melt in your mouth. If you weren't going for a full on meal, you go in, order drinks and baked oysters and your in heaven!! We're big eaters though, so we continue..The Vareniki could have been skipped in my opinion, good, but not out of this world. They are essentially a take on potato dumplings, but I preferred the truffle mashed potatoes. Paired with the Sole stuffed with scallops and other seafood, this meal was one for the books! No room for dessert this time, but I'll be back!

photos.caption: Photo of Bob Bob Ricard - Soho, London, United Kingdom. Baked Sole with Champagne Sauce, truffle potatoes and Crushed Peppered Sweet Corn. The only thing here to skip was the corn..
Photo of Bob Bob Ricard - Soho, London, United Kingdom. The Red room
Photo of Bob Bob Ricard - Soho, London, United Kingdom. Press for Champagne!!

P9pqDG0cMrwRTOfEw4SKdw.text: Food was good, and service was great. The reason for the 3 stars, is because of the supposed dress code. We even called and chatted with the host, and was told elegant was the standard. We had not packed elegant attire, so we actually went shopping right before, to meet the requirement. We arrive and....everyone in the restaurant was wearing jeans, or casual clothing (one group was in yoga pants and sweats!). We felt super uncomfortable in our cocktail dresses, and would've gladly worn something more relaxed, had we not been told otherwise. Wish we had known.

6iF9Ni84xvZ7umc7G5yEMg.text: Unassuming from the outside, so much British, inside is hushed and opulent, the greeting warm and speedy. Two rooms, blue on the ground, red downstairs. Both swanky. My host chose the blue room with windows, but who looked outside?The show was inside, in this fancifully decorated quasi Art Deco ish room with hints of bags of money stashed somewhere. The champagne button, a funny touch, works.Fancy chow, fancy prices, and what a wine list!Expensive, a bit too too, and it was great fun!Enjoy!

cPfS5KB7NuwaH623UgbSdA.text: Beautiful restaurant and great service, but too much hype.If you want to stunt on the 'gram (instagram, it's what the kids say) and look at pretty decor, go here.If you want AMAZINGGGGGG food and drinks, there's probably way better places that are not too far. I had heard that this place is kinddddddaaaa a letdown. But I still wanted to go. I took myself there during the week. I was sat at the bar, which was fine. I ordered everything I wanted. Steak tar-tar AND steak AND fries AND bread AND dessert AND champagne AND a rhubarb gin and tonicI think it came out to about £70, which I'm like.... ok, that isn't a TERRIBLE price for such a posh dining experience. But was it the best meal I've ever had? NO!!I do like that it's opened very late. My dinner reservation was at 10pm, and could have been even later if I had wanted it to be! The steak was pretty good. I did enjoy the steak tar-tar as well. Portions were kind of on the small side, but again, fancy restaurant. The decor is amazingly beautiful though. And I think it would make a great spot for a late night dessert and drink. Their signature dessert is actually not to be missed. It's chocolaty and has a fabulous presentation. I heard that they are offering 25% off on Mondays.

zzga7ToQ00I3VygOESuyeg.text: When looking for a fun, indulgent dinner while visiting friends in London I came across Bob Bob Ricard. The "press for champagne" buttons and lavish art-deco decor caught my eye and I suggested this restaurant for our "fancy night" of the trip! Reservations are necessary and the dress code is "elegant", though I noticed a bit of a range from nice (dark jeans and a blouse) to full on gowns among our fellow diners. Though we were a few minutes late for our reservation (got stuck behind a protest in our Uber and had to walk the last few blocks!) the staff were friendly and accommodating, seating us immediately at our table with, as promised, the "press for champagne" button! I ordered the chicken kiev and my friends had the steak tartare and the Bavette steak with truffle sauce. We also shared the Creme brûlée and the BBR signature chocolate glory for dessert. All of our entrees were delicious! The chocolate dessert was beautiful and very yummy (and fruity), but as a whole we preferred the Creme brûlée, which arrived flaming and delicious! I felt like the experience and quality of the food and service was very on par with the price of the meal, so even though it was nicer than I would typically choose it was worth it! A really nice experience that I would recommend.

photos.caption: Photo of Bob Bob Ricard - Soho, London, United Kingdom. The cutest champagne button!
Photo of Bob Bob Ricard - Soho, London, United Kingdom. Chicken Kiev- delicious, including the sweet corn base!

ePB5r_N-dlLJIZe3MMRbzg.text: Bob Bob Ricard is all about the classy but stylish ambiance, the amusing "Press for Champagne" button, the number one beef Wellington in town, and the bedazzled signature chocolate glory. That's pretty much all you need to know.

photos.caption: Photo of Bob Bob Ricard - Soho, London, United Kingdom. BBR Signature Chocolate Glory (13.50) - chocolate Jivara mousse, chocolate brownie, berries and passionfruit & orange jelly
Photo of Bob Bob Ricard - Soho, London, United Kingdom. Beef Wellington for Two (46.50 per person) - 28 day aged fillet of Scotch beef
Photo of Bob Bob Ricard - Soho, London, United Kingdom. "Press for Champagne" Button

puJjFinilVdzk8N3IgLSlQ.text: I wanted to like Bob Bob Ricard more than I actually did. I think it deserves a 5 star for decor, service, and atmosphere but the food was a solid 3 for me. The restaurant itself is stunning; everything is opulently decorated from the pink and gold china to the gilded walls and luxurious "press for champagne" button at each table. Unfortunately the food just didn't match up for me. My friend and I started with the crab and avocado salad and the shrimp and fish dumplings. The dumplings were good but nothing to write home about while the crab salad tasted like very fishy crab with a smear of avocado cream. It was not fresh tasting at all and I honestly took two bites and the decided that was enough. For our entrees we had chicken Kiev and the Dover sole with lobster champagne sauce. The chicken was excellent but my Dover sole tasted a bit off and the creamy lobster champagne sauce was a bit heavy. Perhaps the food just wasn't my taste, I was just hoping for better. I did love the side of roast vegetables though; they were easily the best thing we ordered. I would come back to Bob Bob Ricard for drinks as the atmosphere is amazing but might skip the food next time.

ivOHgOM8M8LVlWmIZ7LXzg.text: You want luxury over the top? You want a menu fitting a rock star or a russian oligarch? You want a button by your table you simply press to get a glass of champagne?  Three words: BOB BOB RICARD. This is where you should go. Im sure you are well aware of the Gatsby-ish interior if you are reading this review so ill keep it short. Lets just say its stunning either you end up in the red or blue dining room. How about the food then? Yes the food is up to par with the rest. Here is what we tried on the menu: *Oysters Brezhnev (5) delicous high quality parmesanbaked oysters topped with truffle. Whats there not to love? *Pelmini with a beef/tea broth (4,5)  Delicious little russian dumplings in a gorgeous broth packed with flavors. Very good!*Beef tartar with foie gras (4) The tartar was very good as well with cute little cubes of foie gras as a nice touch. While it was very good it was not the best i have tried. For the luxurious ones you can also top this dish with osetra caviar....*Beef Wellington. (+5!) Wow this was the most amazing Beef Weelington i have tasted. The puff pastry was beautiful and crunchy on the outside and light and fluffy inside. The steak was perfect medium-rare and the truffle ju together with the duxelle layer was packed with umami flavors. This is not cheap at 90 £ but its a royal dinner for 2.  We skipped the sides and where happy as we could barely finish the delicios beef. Service was friendly without being overbearing and the champagne button is a must try (duh....).  One can argue that its expensive as the total check was almost identical with the one we had at 2 Michelin star "Dinner by Heston" but its really two completly different restaurants even though i give them both 5 stars. Would love to come back.

photos.caption: Photo of Bob Bob Ricard - Soho, London, United Kingdom. Clarified Bloody Mary
Photo of Bob Bob Ricard - Soho, London, United Kingdom
Photo of Bob Bob Ricard - Soho, London, United Kingdom

wtge-ZLZBR7g0xRyQDTrsg.text: Press for Champagne is the gimmicky button which attracted press to Bob Bob Ricard but the gimmick stops there.The food is delicious and I would come back to try more!!!Celebrating my friend new job we bathed our dinner with a bottle of Champagne which was serve in beautiful heavy crystal glasses.We shared the pelmini (Russian beef and pork dumplings) in beef broth. The stuffing was a but hard (probably more beef in the mix vs pork) but the dumplings paste as perfect and the broth just as delicious. Its a must try!!!! As main, my friend had the onglet and really like it (havent tasted it but it sure looked yummy).I had the fish pie and it was really good and the crust was just a pleasure to eat and look at.Desserts:My friend had the chocolate fondant (didnt try it but looked really good) I had the sour cherry souffle and it was a very good souffle, I would recommend it!All in all this is a great place to celebrate something special (they even got us a small free cake but it was really disgusting but its the intention that counts) the food is not innovative but its deliciously tasty!

Photo of Bob Bob Ricard - Soho, London, United Kingdom. Sour cherry souffle: yummy
Photo of Bob Bob Ricard - Soho, London, United Kingdom. Chocolate fondant: deliciously classic

C1ZX6ugvh48isP4M1cntyA.text: Can't say i was terribly impressed.Service was ok, tried too hard, came off looking pushy.Started with the bloody mary's. One of the worst i have had. At about £13, you'd expect they would know how to make such a simple drink. Warm tomotao juice, lack of ice, no salt or pepper, hardly any kick to it. Alcohol, none that i could taste.  Really poor.Additionally a double gin and tonic, £25, tiny glass, bit of a joke. I'm used to london prices, a martini at the connaught is similar pricing and it's worth it but BBR is a bit silly.Food. Had two filet mignon rossini, was fine, nothing that special. Chicken pie, again fine, did the trick but that's about all. Lobster mac and cheese, from the hype i had heard, pretty disappointing. Side of carrorts, fine.All of the food needed extra seasoning.Dessert, the creme brulee and eton mess. The eton mess was a unique display of the dessert but looked better than it tasted.All in all, an average dinner experience and i shall not be coming back. There are many better places to go....

Photo of Bob Bob Ricard - Soho, London, United Kingdom. The most expensive G&T in London, tiny and average for 25, also known as daylight robbery

MIkDQ9Wji0OndF3T7Rlb8g.text: I hate to leave BBR with two stars, but I was rather unimpressed with the food and service here.  Particularly at its price point, I had great expectations which became increasingly deflated during the course of the meal.  The restaurant itself is gorgeous and as I visited during the Christmas season, it was really festive.  The smell of cinnamon and warm spices hit me as I walked in the door which was a great touch - I'm a sucker for small details like this that get me in the holiday spirit.  Everyone loves the novel "press for champagne" button located at each table, which is cute albeit slightly gimmicky.  Our group's orders were taken an hour after we settled in which isn't a big deal since we were all busy chatting away but this idleness seemed to be a theme throughout the night and we waited a while for everything from water refills to our courses. I had the crab salad and salmon tartare which were both fine, but nothing to write home about.  The salmon tartare had a mass of overly sweet pickled fennel on top which I think took away from the dish.  The fennel was also simultaneously really acidic and gave the raw salmon a strange semi-cooked texture.  Perhaps I ordered the wrong dishes as two of my friends really enjoyed the beef wellington, but to me the meal was a bit underwhelming.

kjtnOTAp7WuDtSeqqklazA.text: Update Seems only right that I update my review after the event on Sunday, and I'm more than happy to. Because BBR seems to have gotten even better since I went not long after they first opened. And they're really really good now. The private room is stunning (and you absolutely have to nose about in the bathrooms) and the services is impeccable. Am I ever going to order salmon roe again? Nope. Will you find my in the bar drinking more rhubarb gin 'n' tonics than is good for me? Yes. Even that's got better since my review last year. I love it here. Wish I had an excuse to come back more often. * Oh my goodness I've died and gone to Art Deco heaven. This. Place. Rules. Seriously, it's one of the best restaurants I've been to in London. I came here last night for dinner and we had such a lovely time. The meal was fantastic and the service was second to none. They've got a bar downstairs, but that wasn't open. Despite us initially not wanting dinner, they were happy to let us sit in the restaurant and have drinks. but, of course, we ended up eating anyway. It's not cheap here. Not at all. In fact, with extras and sides and champagne and stuff I imagine your bill could easily shoot through the roof. But, a cheeseburger was an acceptable £12.50. Yes, it's a lot. But it was the best cheeseburger I've had and my friend agreed. Most mains will set you back about £20. The drinks are fab. Although I wasn't a big fan of my Rhubarb gin and tonic - not enough rhubarb in it and it comes in a teeny tiny glass. but the wine was great. It's the service and decor that makes this place stand out. Toasters on the tables at breakfase. A button to push if you want champagne (soooooo close to pressing it just for fun). They've got the art deco thing bang on. Stunning bathrooms. The service was just the right side of attentive. but only just. We all agreed that had they been any nicer, it would have been irritating. But we were charmed, fed, watered and left happy and a bit in love with the place. It was quiet, and I think it would be much nicer for breakfast, but the menu is a bit all over place so I imagine it's still trying to work out its niche. Cocktails, wine, dinner etc and we only spent £25 per head with service. Worth every penny.

UEJcv8196sx_jK1oi_9yfQ.text: Crikey, I've just stepped back in time.Oh no wait, that hostess is holding an iPad.  My mistake.Bob Bob Ricard manages to combine the decadence of the 1920s with the technology of 2012.  Even more impressively, it's virtually impossible to identify whether it's authentically art deco or merely reproduction.  Belying our defiantly unposh natures by painstakingly investigating our immediate surroundings (picture the scene; bums in the air, faces to the table, fingernails scratching away at the varnish), my drinking companions and I eventually concluded that the leather backing on the seat was too clean and soft to be more than a few years old. Wikipedia confirms our suspicions: it was built in 2008.  But it was an admirable effort, Bob.  Bravo.It's beautifully decorated, faux or otherwise; deep red leather seat backs, overly-ornate brass railings, wall-splayed mirrors with a hint of cigarette-steeped tarnish (though of course it was built after the smoking ban) and an angular logo all add to the lush allure of 1920s opulence.  Add a couple of flip-up bus-stop seats and a floor decorated like a gigantic backgammon board and you're in business.I've not eaten here but the cocktails are splendid.  Yes, they're expensive, but I've pondered whether or not this deserves the loss of a star and frankly I don't think that it does.  You can see the menu outside.  The upmarket style is obvious.  If you're greeted by a maitre'd and two assistants who silently take your coats and whisk you to a lovely corner booth without so much as a by-your-leave, you know you're in for a treat and you ought to know you're going to have to pay for it.  At roughly £10 per cocktail, it's not astonomical, nor is it a "quick drink after work" type of a venue . . . but maybe one to pull out of the bag if you're planning to impress a date.  It's got the mood lighting, the table service which just verges on the right side of overly-attentive, the exquisitely-presented drinks and enough atmosphere to give you something to talk about when the conversation runs dry.  You can't pay for that.Except you can.  It'll cost you £10 a drink.That's just cheap at the price.

iyR4mosTw-AYtdJ2yPGthw.text: Why so many food bloggers and (some) critics think this restaurant is any good is totally beyond me. This is the most preposterous, stupidly expensive pile of pretentious nonsense in the whole of London. There's no doubting the effort that has gone into the hilarious décor, reminiscent of the Orient Express in the 1930s, and the attention to detail in all the fittings, and the comfort and privacy of the booths. But the food is so gut-wrenchingly bad, pointless and random, and so outrageously expensive for what it is, served by sneering, half-witted waiters, that this place should be closed for offences to basic decency. I am baffled, just baffled, that this moronic establishment is popular and well-regarded.

LzrCExbeBLp94V-I9WsGLg.text: I have been here twice now: once for dinner and once for breakfast. Overall, great place, good food. Dinner. Started with drinks at the downstairs bar. Struck me that they were a little understaffed as it took a long time to get a menu and place our orders. Rhubarb gin and tonics are stunning - but very easy to drink quickly. Overall, I think their prices are too high on cocktails. Bar snacks (blanched almonds and olives) do not reflect the high price of drinks, although the olives are tasty. Music selection of the bar is terrible in my opinion, it should be better matched to the decorations which is more jazz and lounge. I wish they would also turn the lights down as it felt like we were in a Weatherspoons. The booths in the restaurant are superb. A great way to make you feel relaxed with your fellow diners, and also feel a little private. Champagne call button is a great idea. When I ate their the champagne trolley was unavailable. However, did try their champagne and I feel they have got their pricing totally wrong. No glass for under £12. I know the place is upmarket, but in reality who is going to press the button for another glass when they are notching up at least £12 each time. Also, no bottles under £100. Ridiculous. Food was great. I liked being able to have a breakfast/brunch item as a starter - I opted for the Eggs Arlington which was very very good. Mains were fine. Desserts seemed a highlight. The souffles were stunning. Breakfast. While it lacks the buzz of the Wolseley, it is a great places for a quiet business breakfast or a late lazy brunch. Coffees were ok but not great. Service was very attentive, polite and professional. Toasters on the table is a great idea but I thought the bread selection was poor. A plain white and wholemeal option, with no sourdough. I cannot believe they have the cheek to charge over £3 for a bowl of cornflakes! Price. Not the cheapest of places and perhaps a bit more expensive than the Wolseley its nearest competitor. But enjoyable and very stylish. I think a late night dinner is a great way to enjoy this place but easy on the champagne unless you want an astronomical bill.

DwnWigORA0OopqfGR-G5fg.text: please also seehungryinlondon.com/2010/…  Food and Wine Blogger dinners are a great opportunity to meet and socialise with other food bloggers and enjoy good value food in interesting restaurants (thank you Niamh for organising!). This time it took place at Bob Bob Ricards in Soho. Bob Bob Ricard is a super stylish and decadent, Russian themed restaurant with  very importantly  a pink champagne emergency button on each table; the evening was off to a promising start! It indeed commenced very well with the BBR signature cocktail  a delicious rhubarb gin & tonic (7.5). In fact I have to say that all the drinks to come were delightful. However, I personally was not convinced about the food. After having read all these enthusiastic reviews out there and when considering the clearly higher than average prices, I would have expected more. For me, the food lacked finesse and sophistication and was in general confused. The first 2 courses were to be enjoyed together with chilled (-18 degrees) vodka (very nice vodka indeed: Vodka Imperia by Russian Standard (4.75) and Vodka Kauffman Special Selected Vintage 2006 (7.50) paired to the respective dishes). We were explained exactly how first to sip the ice cold vodka, immediately followed by a some food  this did add an interesting aspect to the whole experience. However, I still did not particularly like the ox tongue in jelly with horseradish (7.50) and neither was I very convinced about the second starter. I mean it was not bad, Russian salad with fresh shavings of truffles and some thin toast on the side just seemed a bit crude and did not quite do it for me. I think I have discovered for myself that I am not keen on the combination of mayonnaise and truffles. I have to say that I found the main dish hideous. The whole concept of veal holstein (21.50) seems somehow wrong in general and sadly also seemed wrong at Bob Bob Ricard: A lovely veal escalope in bread crumbs (basically a Wiener Schnitzel), very nice by itself, disappeared in an amalgamation of random flavours: it was lying on top of mashed potatoes. the potatoes were seasoned with truffle oil. then there was the quail egg on top of the veal. and some anchovies and capers.some crispy bacon on the side, and some tomatoes. Did I forget anything? Oh yes, the secret sauce. a major culinary confusion, I just think very often less is more The dessert Chocolate Glory (8.74) was fun.It basically looked like a a gargantuan Christmas ornament. Hot chocolate sauce was poured on top and revealed an inside of Chocolate mousse and brownie as well as some fruit jelly. Even though I actually quite enjoyed it, I again thought there were just too many different parts randomly combined. Have I mentioned that I am a firm believer in less is more? I had a lovely evening, I met nice and interesting people, I liked the atmosphere, the style and the booze and would full-heartedly recommend Bob Bob Ricard for drinks in a pleasant and different atmosphere. However, for me the food was a failure For pictures of the food I refer you to An American Cupcake in London (they site to follow if you love baking). (We got served a set menu for 40 pounds including drinks  I have however indicated the prices as they appear in the normal menu.)

hskSXtjLV1Ns_8xnDTr3Ng.text: This is one of the most impressive places I've been to in a while. From the decor (a lovely spin on Art Deco, a period that I adore) to the little gimmicks (hello, 'press for champagne' button!) to the delectable food and drinks. This place was recommended to me, and I can see why...I can't actually think of anything negative to say because Bob Bob Ricard exceeded my expectations. Moreover, I went to take a peek at the downstairs bar and fell even more in love with the resto. It's definitely a place for a special night out, and I know that it won't be long until I go back.

-bXuV1uCgDw1P81RSmBO6w.text: What a dissapointment. I had been looking forward to going here for a while, however, when I eventually went for breakfast last week I was bitterly dissapointed. Decor was pleasant, service was ok, not brilliant but certainly not bad either. I opted for the eggs benedict, my friend had the eggs royale. It come with bread to toast yourself in the provided toaster. This was all very well but the toaster took about 15 minutes to toast the bread. When the food come, my eggs benedict was at best luke warm! Now I hate to sound snobbish, but when I am paying £25-£30 for breakfast, I am sorry but I don't expect to find 4 stonking big thumb prints around my plate. Maybe down the local cafe but not in a supposedly 'fine dining' establishment. I would bet any money that this place will be gone inside 2 years. A typical example of all style and no substance. I have had better breakfasts for less than a tenner, in fact maybe even less than a fiver!

0KAVsEkrhIg5P_Yl-6FjEg.text: This place is freaking awesome. Imagine, in your mind, a glamorous 1930s art deco restaurant. It's got glass and brass and tables for two. It's got a cool bar in the basement, with little fold-down seats in alcoves and ice bucket baskets. The servers have uniforms, and they fuss over you. There are fringes of velvet, chain-link dividers topping the booth walls, and eveything is polished. Every object in the place also bears the logo of the establishment. This place is twice as nice as you're thinking it is. And not only is it retro-cool, but it has the touches the other reviewers have mentioned: toasters at the table for breakfast so you can make your toast precisely the way you like it, and hot. A button at each table to call for champagne. Polished granite. Coat hangers secreted in slots alongside the table. Yes, it's pricey. An English breakfast is nearly £13. But it's one of the best I've ever had (the egg's yolk was deep orange, the black pudding was moist and flavourful, the coffee rich and delicious). Same for my wife's eggs benedict. But you could also get toast and jam for less than £5, or some grapefruit, or a bowl of porridge. You don't have to splash out if you don't want to, there's a range of choices and prices. It is too expensive to be my regular, but for special occasions I think this place is super. This is posh retro done right. It opens from 7:30am for breakfast, and it's open for lunch and dinner, too. The basement bar opens at 6pm and stays open until 3am! It's an all-day experience. I can't say enough about the service. Smiles, everyone, smiles! Go. Go, or be doomed to a life less fulfilled than it could be. EDIT: 07-Dec-08I hate to say this, but I have to downgrade BBR a star based on my experiences there last night. A group went for a Xmas dinner. The food was fabulous, although the dinner menu isn't extensive and it is a bit pricey. The service was top-notch. In fact, it was a little too much. There seemed to be large numbers of people milling about our table at all times. In their effort to try so hard, it seemed like little thins kept going wrong: a glass was dropped and shattered at our table, and a tray of water was tipped over onto our bags. I don't hold any ill will, they were definitely accidents, but the whole service felt a bit pressurized. And though we got great service in the bar downstairs afterwards - which we were about the only ones in - and some really great drinks, the A/C was pumped way up so that it was FREEZING. We asked them to dial it back, and they did, but it's hard to believe they could have expected anyone to sit there. The restaurant's only 2 weeks old, so I hope they sort these growing pains out and go back to being perfect.

AJyKXmBwBLQVeV_YEfWViQ.text: It says a lot about this sumptuous Soho restaurant that there are buttons on the walls inviting diners to "press for champagne". What it says, specifically, is Wow. Invited to a tasting by the good people at Qype, our group were treated on arrival to a deliciously delicate rhubarb gin & tonic, followed by a selection of fine Russian vodkas, punctuated with some robust Russian snacks to help us stay focused. If I were advising general visitors (or at least those who would flinch from paying £15 for a pour of the admittedly smooth Kauffman Private Collection Luxury Vintage), I'd strongly recommend the Russian Standard Imperia at a very reasonable four-pounds-something a shot, accompanied by a plate of meat pelmeni (£12.50), which are best described as dumplings for kings (pairing well with, er, vodka). For the less adventurous, but equally demanding, I hear their burgers are a triumph. Service at this stylish Anglo-Russian eatery-cum-vodkary is as impeccable as the aqua upholstery is opulent. And if you're still not satisfied, just press the button.

u1c7_DkP1u8cMrav023Fvw.text: do not go there for brunch! despite great service and lush surrounds - the scrambled eggs were watery, bacon burnt and pancakes dry and clearly not fresh. For £12 - forget it. As my friend said - even Mackers is 100% better food.

AIDMCKu1z0XY0UdmjcHUog.text: For photos see Greedy Diva @ greedydiva.blogspot.com/…  Bob Bob Ricard is fun. Lots of fun. A whole big bucket of jumping castle fun. I will declare my heart on my sleeve from the outset. I love Bob Bob (real name Leonid). I love Ricard (real name Richard). And I love vodka (real name vodka). Sure, BBR fed me free shots of vodka all night. But, I'm Australian - it takes a lot before the beer goggles (or vodka goggles, as the case may be) take effect on us. I was not actually expecting to like BBR quite so much. It's glitzy, extravagant and over-the-top in every way - so often a warning flag that there's a bit of style over substance going on. But I managed to bag a place along with a table full of other bloggers to Bob's Vintage Vodka tasting in mid February, so I thought I'd give it a fair shot (pun intentional). Naturally, this was not your average dining experience - unless you habitually shoot 8 shots of vodka with your meal - and our every whim was entertained by the fabulous owners who dined and drank with us all evening. I haven't yet dined at BBR incognito, but plan to go back based on my positive experience thus far - so this is not a critique of BBR so much as an enthusiastic rant about their fabulous event at which I was a paid for guest. And I must declare another interest - I'm a vodka girl from way back. However, my vodka appreciation has always been more in the nature of late night mindless enthusiasm, often involving a martini glass, so I was interested to hear some of the theory behind the madness. One does not enter the world of BBR without noticing the interior. It's glammed up, eccentric, flamboyant and quirky, from the gold fittings and green booths, to the marble and leather, and the much spoken of "Press Here for Champagne" buzzers. The intention is to be something of a morning til late "Wolseley style" brasserie. I found it much like stepping into a scene from Alice In Wonderland. This is not a place for cynics, but walk in with an open mind and you might end up enjoying yourself as much as I did. Despite appearances, BBR specialises in old fashioned, posh(ish) British fare, with the frequent Russian twist. We kicked off proceedings with the BBR Signature Pink Rhubarb Gin & Tonic, which was lovely and refreshing and intended to sum up the ethos - fun, British and extra pink. Then the real business began. First up, the Vodka Kauffman Special Selected Vintage 2006 (RRP around £70), paired with jellied ox tongue with creamed horseradish. This was my favourite vodka of the night, and one of my favourite courses. The ox tongue was prettily presented and the bite of the horseradish cut through the delicate aspic and meat beautifully. The Kauffman Special is a wheat vodka made from a single harvest in a vintage year - soft and pure, it's the lack of flavour that makes a good vodka (signalling less impurities and more thorough distillation and filtering, sometimes involving silver or quartz). The less you can taste, the better it is. This concept is one that's tricky for the hardened wine drinker to get one's head around. Nonetheless, the message was that the vodka clears the palate, warms the soul, and is to be followed by a mouthful-of-food chaser to enhance the food's flavour. It didn't always for me, although it certainly cleansed the palate. In any case, I enjoyed the whole ceremonial aspect of shooting from a small, kitschy vodka glass before tasting my food and I'm seriously contemplating introducing the ritual around the home kitchen table. Our remaining courses proceeded as follows: The Vodka Kauffman Private Collection Luxury Vintage 2003 (RRP around £140) served with caviar, blinis and sour cream. My heartfelt love of blinis is no secret. Intermission bites: Wafer thin cured Orkney beef with a celeriac salad, fresh blueberries and roasted hazelnuts; pickled beetroot and goat's cheese salad with fresh mint; potted shrimp; and a delicious rabbit, foie gras and date terrine. Next was the Russian Standard Vodka (popular in Russia, and retails here for around £15) served with Russian salt-cured herring, raw onion rings and new potatoes. The food was delicious. The vodka tasted like vodka. Imperia by Russian Standard was served with salmon roe on hard boiled quail's egg. The Beluga (our first malt based vodka for the evening) was paired with quail's egg mayonnaise with anchovies. Again, a surprisingly tasty combo. The Vodka Beluga Gold Line (another malt based vodka) was paired with some scrumptiously moreish meat pelmeni (Russian dumplings consisting of pork, beef and chopped onions - delicious with either vinegar or sour cream). We finished up the tasting with 2 Stolichnaya vodkas - the Vodka Stolichnaya Gold served with salo on rye bread (lard - not my thing, but was rapturously devoured by lard loving Lizzie) and the Vodka Elite served with malosol cucumbers. These were the vodkas with the most impurities, to be scoffed at by

-XNUrNdiMG4DwPaiDMJYVA.text: I just don't get this place. We had lunch on a Saturday and in spite of recent (positive) Time Out reviews, the place was half empty and dramatically lacking buzz In the middle of Soho, 50m away from both Picadilly and regent Street, Bob Bob Ricard still hasn't quite started to engage Londoners. They have achieved something pretty bad, ie BBR (as they like to call the place since the name is not really great) looks and feels like it's part of a chain while it's not! It is a D E S T I N A T I O N restaurant, our (French, extremely nice and attentive) maitre d'hotel told us. The problem is that while they have clearly spent a lot of money to turn what used to be a minimalist 90s restaurant (Circus for those who remember) into a kind a art deco railway station restaurant (St Lazare?) meets TGI Friday meets Tim Burton Maybe it was the blue or pink wastecoats of the waiters or the clear lack of experience of the staff (apart from the M.O.) or the fact that it all looked too new and half empty. Then the big (and real) disappointment was the food. Nothing really worth talking about, nothing special, the mash was supposed to be delicious and it wasn't, the hamburger was nice but at £12 really steep, the tomatoes and pasta not that good really Overall a big disappointment. They do have a few original features, like the toaster on teh table or the champagne button (at £12 a glass according to a reviewer below!), but BBR feels too much like trying to entertain without the substance nor the consumer success (so far). So I will stay away, at least for a while while the tweak the offering (the waiter did confess that the menu was going to change). It could be a good place for breakfast as their menu is really more about breakfast (think about the toaster!) than dinner (few main courses and a steak at £28 pp with 4 person minimum order!). But since they are open from 7am to 3am every day apparently, it is a good name to keep on the little black book as so few decent places are open that late. In any event have a go, it IS different and I hope you will have a better experience than me to talk about on Qype

1G9HwNlsIT9BmGmdsw8JgA.text: I went after hearing about the champagne button and came away delighted by the experience. My best dinner out in months.The facade is subtle and easily missed but for the two pink jacketed liverymen who let us in to their strange parallel universe. Everything about this place is weirdly retro, polished and ultimately sublime. Seating is in comfortable booths with single seat tables (!) at the front and larger ones for groups. The lighting evokes a speakeasy but the formal uniforms would fit at the Ritz, if they weren't flamboyantly pink. In the end I stopped trying to understand this conjuration and just enjoyed it.The menu offers breakfast, lunch and dinner options all day as well as a full range of drinks from milkshakes to vodka. First order of business was to hit the champagne button and we went with their Rose (to match the decor). Sadly I didn't get to press it again as the staff always materialised the instant my glass approached empty. Food-wise I had pickled herring, meat pelmeni and a peach compote brule prompted by reminiscences of  the Russian countryside (the owner is also Russian).  The entertainment continued with the maître des rêves suggesting vodka to accompany the pelmeni, which appeared at the appropriate moment chilled to minus 18 degrees.One final comment, it was amazing to be served by attentive, enthusiastic well-trained staff who clearly enjoy what they do. There was never anything wanting and I will definitely be returning either for dinner or the members bar downstairs. I cannot recommend it enough.

h8JYTkSDDFJLf2CW40djMA.text: for my last night out in london, my friend made a reservation at BBR.  this is a really pretty restaurant and a good place for a last hurrah.  it was pretty empty for the 27th, but since it's a bank holiday, londoners were still out of town.  we skipped the apps and went straight to the mains.  i had the tuna carpaccio nicoise w/ a side of brussels and chestnuts.  they ran out of lobster and chips tonight, which was kinda a bummer, but my friend got the lobster burger, which looked good.  chicken kiev, the veg burger, and mac and cheese rounded out the rest of our orders.for dessert, we got a strawberry souffle and the chocolate special dessert (forgot the name).  they were both decadent but delicious.drinks here are fantastic.  this is a great place to go for a special occasion.

QMfN7dLWbes0CUHi2SqiUQ.text: Fantastic. Expensive. Delicious. Chicken and truffle pie was a little disappointing in size compared to the size of the dish it was served in... But tasty! Don't snooze on the chocolate gold dessert. Jeremiah was quite charming as well! Also who doesn't dig a button at your table that screams "push for champagne"?!!!

7GtMHuVBAGSfZSusdzdLlA.text: I had heard that Bob Bob Ricard was good for afternoon tea so it had been on my radar for awhile, but actually only went there after i happened upon it on a leisurly walk.  The best part of this place is the decor.  Its very retro and cute with a "more champagne" button at every booth.  I didn't go for tea so i can't vouch for that, but i was a bit dissapointed with the meal.  It was rather expensive for a small mediocre meal.  It also took awhile for the food to come.  There was only one other couple in the place while we were there so not really sure why it took so long...so anyway..this place's only saving grace is the decor. if you want to feel like you are in L.A. Confidential come here.  but don't expect the service to live up to that glamorous vibe.

urw2xLsX17WLXvDbjrf4Sg.text: Luxurious dinning room (and bathrooms!) with attentive (bordering "stiff") service make this a compelling option for an expense account lunch or a long-overdue noontime reunion with an old friend (or new object of attraction).  The food didn't live up to the grandeur of the space but was reasonably priced on the prix fixe luncheon menu.

eqh3LPIKtZgGYSg6WWNLLg.text: I think I'm in love with this place. The beautiful turqoise accents, the weird little retro robot toys sitting on the shelf in the private room, the chandeliers, the hot pink, the china - everything. I came here with some othe lucky Qypers for a vodka tasting and sampling of some delicious Russian nibbles (there was promise of a roast too, but we were all so full from gorging ourselves on yumminess, we couldn't even fathom having more food!) Truth be told, there are some off-the-wall items on the menu that the faint of heart (or stomach) might not go for. However, I'll try anything once - and things like jellied ox tongue or salo (pork fat served on rye bread) were surprisingly good. Must give a major thumbs up for the salted caramel ice cream too! It's not cheap, but for a special and gastrologically adventurous night out, it should be your top choice in Soho.

A8dEeVbm9gHU7UKtyk0wew.text: Full review and photos at thehappinessprojectlondo…  Inside its gorgeous  you sit in comfy private booths surrounded by brass rails and little curtains - very Orient Express with great lighting and modern touches too. For a Saturday it was super quiet but that may have been due to the footie. I'd love to come back and try some vodka and Zakuski (things like salmon roe on quail's egg and Russian herring) which reminds me of an amazing Latvian meal I had round at my friend G's flat in Paris where we drank enough home-made vodka to make our hair curl, but woke up hangover-less and happy  these Eastern types know a thing or two about having a good time. But instead we plumped for starters and mains. First things first, you must start with cocktails  an amazing Rhubarb G&T and EL G had a refreshing BBR Botanical. For starters, El G had cured orkney beef and celeriac salad with blueberries and hazelnuts and I had the potted shrimp with baby watercress  like everything we ate that night I loved the interesting flavour combinations which were perfectly balanced - both were really tasty. I heard the chateaubriand was amazing but at £32 it was a bit out of our price range, so I ordered the veal holstein with anchovies, a quail's egg, truffle mash and secret sauce which was beautiful  amazingly well cooked, really light and incredible textures and flavours. El G had the chicken kiev (well surely it would be authentic here?) with sweetcorn mash which again was perfectly cooked and tasty. We washed this all down with a lovely bottle of chablis (£35). We were impressed at the lack of giant mark ups in the wine - not that we could afford the more expensive bottles, but the wine list shows how much other restos charged for the same bottle (often double). We finished off by sharing a plate of cheese with the most creamy brie I've ever had and a glass or merlot and port, followed by home-made chocolate truffles and coffee. We felt incredibly spoiled and left really happy after 3 hours of totally unrushed but great service which for me is the sign of a great meal. The bill came to £170 or £85 each so it ain't cheap but it was a wonderfully different, luxurious treat and I'm definitely coming back!

f5XndcuAgme9bU3vmVkhqw.text: Many thanks to Qype for inviting me along to the vodka tasting event here. Having heard great things of the art deco interior, 'press for champagne' buttons and famous burgers, I'd been itching to go for ages. First up I have to comment on the decor. It's an art deco masterpiece, all green and amber glass, mirrors, mixed woods, dark romantic lighting and a touch of the members club. You'll know instantly if you love it or not - but rest assured there's nothing else like it in London. Seated in the private dining area off from the diner-goes-glam main restaurant, we were greeted with the amazing rhubard gin and tonics (you MUST have one if you go) and then worked our way through a menu of various Russian style canapes to go with our vodkas. Some weren't really my kind of thing; I wasn't keen on the jellied ox tongue, salmon roe on quails eggs and goats cheese with beetroot. Others - scallops with black pudding (has someone been watching Masterchef?), salted cucumber and potted shrimp I enjoyed a lot more. The general rule seemed to be that salt ruled, because it works so well with the clean flavour of vodka. I oversalt everything so this didn't bother me, but bear it in mind if you don't like it! Though the burger is - and probably will always be - the bestseller, I really recommend the meat Pelmeni, a kind of Russian take on the dumpling / dim sum. Served with sour cream and white vinegar, they were a huge hit with our group - perhaps because their dense stodginess soaked up the £15 a shot vodka we were tasting! Puddings were also gorgeous - I went for chocolate fondant with pistachio ice cream, which was gorgeous. The salted caramel ice-cream seemed to be a winner too.

jQg_Qa4iwsCLXcEhnrCLhA.text: I'm another of the lucky vodka tasters from the weekend and long story short, I rather like BBR. The tasting was excellent, with interesting drinks, good spiel from Ric(h)ard and tasty zakuski to mop up a portion of the alcohol - it's not often that I turn down a Sunday lunch due to snack based repleteness, and I suspect I'll have to go back sometime and see what I missed out on. The food was all very good, with standouts of jellied ox tongue (which the other attendees' fear of jelly allowed to come in my direction a good few times), blaeberry cured beef and meat pelmeni (the russian 'meat wrapped in pasta like thing' dish, which so far for me is winning against the similar things from various other countries). Having a quick look at other diners' plates as I left and scouring the menu there's an interesting variety of comfort food with the occasional more refined twist which looks good, although by no means cheap. We may have been there for an event but the staff seemed to go about their duties in their normal manner - efficient, friendly, polite and all in all great. The place looks good, the service is excellent, the food is tasty and the vodka is cold. You pay for the experience, but you get your money's worth.

K4SwEFIjVyBmNH2Zo0W3vw.text: Food Excellent. Wine list better..... Chateau d'Yquem by the glass.....just HAS to be done!

GXGS_LTOY0v8_OIvsLp1hw.text: Came here a while ago and remember the food was just ok, although the website made it look way better. But this was a fun place to get all dolled up on a weekend and go with a bunch of friends. We were seated in the private room so didn't get a chance to check out the scene outside. The cocktails were the highlight of the night. And the "champagne" call button came in handy. Overall a fun experience and recommend giving it a try.

ZxnUCUIJuapE_slmiC1VQQ.text: I think I want to try the breakfast - seems to be the key meal of the day here. But I had lunch. Love the decor, never happier than when in a warm banquette, love the champagne button, but somehow, somehow I'm just not sure it all comes together. My friend suggested the signature chicken kiev dish, and again it was pretty good. Succulent chicken, nice corn mash a lot of peas and probably better than at a Berni Inn. Probably. The service was very good and I'm told the bar is awesome. But as another reviewer said, it feels like a chain but it should feel like a destination. At these prices it needs to deliver more. I will probably come again (it's local) and as an eggs benedict connoisseur will update my review.

f3DG3xS-RR_pfR9YW8tcrw.text: Their beef wellington is incredible! An experience.And the "Press for Champagne" button!

86NbqX5tLISCvw3pYKsc9g.text: I hate to do this, especially as I had really high hopes for this place (apologies to everyone who's gotten really excited from reading the reviews directly below), but I had a really bad time here two nights ago. The staff, admittedly, were really friendly, but trivial mistakes like completely forgetting to bring us the wine we had ordered meant that we left with a fairly bad impression of them. (It was a relatively quiet night, so they should have had time to run to the fridge.) The restaurant's design is fun and it is suitably cosy on a chilly night, but does anyone else think that the green leather banquettes are reminiscent of the dodgy Aberdeen Angus restaurant down the road? Before you accuse me of pedantry, however, I should say that it's the food that I had the real problem with. Whilst their fish soup was decent, simple dishes such as scotch eggs and a burger were poorly done and simply not worth finishing. Given the other reviews on this site I feel that I've missed out on something spectacular, but I really wouldn't want to eat there again. Perhaps we ordered the wrong things, perhaps we went on a bad night, but we left the restaurant with the distinct feeling that this Bob wasn't worth ours.

F1jfqj1AQckgHY4Vy-MEfA.text: I LOVE Bob Bob Ricard. The rhubarb G&T is to die for, the staff are lovely, and the whole place is pure art deco heaven. The bar downstairs is a bit of a hidden gem - it's like being on the Orient Express in the 1930s, just tuck yourself away in one of the booths with a few of your closest pals and drink the night away (although only until 10pm). Incredibly glamorous, I can't wait to go back.Oh, and the afternoon tea is pretty fabulous too.

Qz7u8QZoc0NA0-hZiyN_Kw.text: What can I say that hasn't been said already about this art deco diner? WOW is simply NOT enough :)

DJd5yG0qrxOqFZOU8Un81w.text: We didn't have a reservation but had no trouble getting seats at the bar.  We ordered the Beef Wellington for two and it was simply outstanding - even with the 45 minute wait.  Before dinner I ordered a blackberry/egg white cocktail concoction which was also fantastic.  Service was attentive and professional, atmosphere was lively but not overbearing - this was definitely the best food we experienced on our trip.

cgT3yKFlmAy52m0ieLPIQQ.text: Beautiful space as others have said and very nice service.  Food, however, was truly mediocre and incredibly expensive.  This is a nice spot for a special occasion drink and dessert but I would pass on the mains and starters and head elsewhere.  Three of us for a business dinner and all felt the same with different meals.

cu5dNpWbwf7PdCAU4Khiog.text: Lots of things have been said about this place, and one thing continues to echo and that is that they are trying to elevate the food quality of this restaurant to make it a new classic in London. With a really highbrow interior design, done by David Collins, the restaurant has a cool retro feel to it, and the details are seen in every inch, gadget and fork in the restaurant. The food is based on English comfort food, but it has added twists to it. The wait staff is dressed to perfectly blend with the interior and the process are above average, but the place is such a lovely space its well worth visiting.

ex13QfhaWdtKOQzKvO_K2A.text: instantly fell in love with bob bob ricard. BBR drips with the unique luxury of what stalin's dining car must have been like orient express meets KGB colonels on their night off, quaffing champagne and caviar. BBR is a triumph of style AND substance. the attention to detail here is very unusual. excellent food from a very tongue-in-cheek menu. good service and a gorgeous bar downstairs. red leather and black marble. the only let down is that last call is at 23:15.
